Theory of emotions and economic analysis:
a review1
Emmanuel Petit*
Since Elster’s seminal review [1998], an abundant literature has revealed the growing interest of economists in the question of emotions.

The introduction of emotion into economic analysis has been carried out essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion. Developing a richer and more complete economy of emotions makes it necessary to also draw on other approaches to emotion, notably from sociology, anthropology, history and philosophy.

The aim of this article is to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions. The first step is to identify the major stages in the construction of this theory and to extract the essential properties of emotions. The aim is then to illustrate how this knowledge has been mobilized in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline.

As in many academic disciplines, economists have accompanied what historians have called the “emotional turn” (Plamper [2010]), an extraordinary craze born in the mid-1990s for the study of emotions.

In economics, emotions are today mainly mobilized and studied in an experimental framework and then introduced into behavioral models in order to improve existing models of human behavior. The “economics of emotions” (Petit [2015]) has made it possible to “revisit” the model of perfect rationality (Elster [1996], Kahneman

As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions.

The introduction of emotion into economic analysis was carried out
essentially from a psychological and neurological conception of emotion.

As suggested by Elster [1998], this conception made it possible (i) to disturb emotion in categories that could be easily mobilized by economists, (ii) to give it a functional (multi-component) definition particularly adapted to the methodological individualism practiced in experimental and behavioral economics and above all (iii) to provide precise and effective instruments for measuring and inducing emotions.

The theory of emotions that was gradually established during the 20th century, however, covers a much broader field of analysis than that taken into account by psychology and neuroscience. Other disciplines – such as sociology, philosophy, anthropology, history and literature – have also constructed an elaborate and fruitful theory of emotions. Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology).

Recent work on the theory of emotions also shows that there is now a convergence between approaches that were once opposed and considered incompatible (biology vs. anthropology, psychology vs. sociology).

Developing a richer and more complete “economy of emotions” makes it necessary to know and draw on the different approaches to emotion, without limiting ourselves to the sole conception of psychology and/or neurology.

The aim of this review is therefore to contribute to enriching the work of economists in this field by proposing a multidisciplinary state of the art that synthesizes the knowledge derived from the theory of emotions.
First of all, it is a question of identifying the main stages in the construction of this theory and extracting the essential properties of emotions (2).

The aim then is to illustrate – as extensively as possible but without claiming to be exhaustive – how this knowledge has been used in economic analysis, taking into account the diversity of approaches characteristic of the discipline (3). We will conclude this review of the literature on the theory and economics of emotions by discussing and identifying the most fruitful and promising areas of research for economists (4).

Abstract
Neo-institutional analysis, and in particular that of Douglass North, has 
attempted to return to the micro foundations of institutions. The 
analytical developments proposed by North and his colleagues focus on the role of 
mental models.

However, they follow the cognitivist turn in the social 
sciences and abandon emotions. The article focuses on the contributions of John Dewey’s 
philosophical thought to an institutional conception that integrates 
the dynamics of emotions to enrich the conception of action and the analysis 
of the link between institutions and the individual. The Contribution of John Dewey’s Theory of Emotions 
to Douglass North’s New Institutional Economics

In his analysis of the formation and evolution of institutions,
Douglass North (1990; 2005) clearly placed himself in a pers -
spective of bounded rationality (Simon, 1982) in order to highlight 
the psychological and social dimensions of individuals’ choices.

In his work on The Process of Economic Development, North 
(2005) attempts to grasp the interactions between cognitive processes, 
belief formation and institutions.

His diagram is, to simplify, “bi-directional” (Ambrosino and Fiori, 2018): beliefs 
guide individuals’ actions and affect institutions and, in 
return, these modify individual beliefs. In this diagram, 
institutions are conceived as regularities of behavior 
and routines that are shared within a population. However, it is only because 
institutions are anchored in the minds of individuals that they can be adapted and 
operational.

This is what, according to Mantzavinos et al. (2004), the singularity and originality 
of the cognitive approach to institutions. At the heart of the approach is therefore a system of individual beliefs 
determined by mental models (Denzau and North, 
1994, Denzau et al., 2016). These models, inherited from the past, 
transmitted from one generation to another, condition the worldview of 
individuals as well as their learning process.

Roy and Denzau 
(2020) recently highlighted the great scope of this cognitive model 
initially presented in the seminal article by Denzau and 
North (1994) and which quickly acquired great notoriety in the 
academic world (the article having been cited more than 3,100 times). The article 
in particular had a strong impact, according to Shugart et al. (2020), on Elinor Ostrom’s institutional economics, development economics, and questions about the role of expertise.

In this article, we suggest that a non-dual approach to emotion, with particular emphasis on its capacity to transform the individual and institutions, allows us to deepen the cognitive project resulting from the aanalysis by North (2005). Widely used by the first players in institutional economics – Veblen, Commons and Ayres – John Dewey in particular proposed a non-dualist thought (Bazzoli and Dutraive, 2013) which is structured around the notion of “transaction” between the individual and the environment (Ballet and Petit, 2019).

Less well-known, his theory of emotions – which he developed in the 1890s and which would be refined in his many subsequent writings – allows us to precisely grasp the dynamic role of emotion during the transaction process.

Dewey’s conception of the notion of transaction and human psychology can thus bring a new perspective to institutional economics. In particular, it allows us to understand how the dynamics of change in institutions are created via emotion. In the first section, we recall the analysis carried out by 
North and his colleagues, in particular the role of mental models in

1. mental models of institutional economics: 
What place for emotion?

In the approach described by North (2005, p. 75), there is “an intimate relationship between belief systems and the institutional framework”. This intimate relationship is expressed in particular with regard to what he calls informal institutions: norms, conventions, but also internally accepted codes of conduct. The centrality of this relationship comes from the fact that the belief system is capable of providing a favorable ground for the creation of productive political and economic institutions (as was the case for the United States) or, on the contrary, of hindering them.

triplets.tail: favorable ground for creation of productive institutions

text: The belief system is thus a central determinant of economic development. The central question in the institutional economics of North and his colleagues (North and Denzau, 1994, Mantzavinos et al., 2004, North, 2005) is therefore to know how the beliefs to which individuals adhere are determined.

1.1. Adaptive “mental models”
To simplify, a belief – or rather, a system of beliefs – 
corresponds to a stabilized mental model that has successfully 
overcome the confrontation with reality. More explicitly, a mental model is 
understood as the most recent prediction that an individual can 
formulate concerning the signals he receives from his environment even before 
these signals have been perceived.

In 
this system, the individual gradually forges mental models during his cognitive 
development that allow him to explain and interpret the world. These models are particularly 
flexible and are produced to deal with a problematic situation, 
particularly when the environment sends signals that are not© Hermann | Downloaded on 01/17/2023 from www.cairn.info via Université de Bordeaux (IP: 147.210.215.16)

not conform to the existing belief system. When we speak 
here of environment, it is, according to the authors, the physical environment 
of the individual but also his sociocultural and linguistic environment.

Some mental models can therefore be 
shared intersubjectively – as is the case, for example, in the presence of ideology. The individual’s knowledge model (learning) is therefore based on a complex and permanent reconfiguration of his/her mental models, which depends in particular on the signals received from his/her environment. In the cognitive model proposed by the new institutional economists, the adaptation of the individual’s mental model – and consequently, the evolution of his/her belief system – naturally depends on the nature and diversity of the signals sent and perceived from his/her environment.

In particular, it may happen that the mental model is unsuitable for the problematic situation that arises. Thus, depending on the degree of adequacy of the mental model with the feedback from its environment, it may be “revised, redefined or otherwise rejected” (Mantzavinos et al., 2004, p. 76, our translation). How, however, can the mental model – that is, the belief system – be changed?

1.2.

Mental models based on an analogical procedure
Starting from the idea that “we are relatively poor at reasoning compared to our ability to understand problems and see solutions [from] implicit knowledge”, North (2005, p. 48) emphasizes that we “perceive, remember, and understand by pattern association”. This is the key to our ability to generalize and use analogies. This enables us not only to model reality but also to construct theories in the face of real uncertainty.

Our beliefs are therefore based on our ability to classify something into one or more classes of objects. The design of mental models of the 
new institutional economics of North posits in summary that the 
belief system is the product of an analogical and/or metaphorical procedure.

According to this cognitive or analogical model, the modification of the system 
is the result of a process in which previously acquired knowledge is reorganized and reused in order to propose a solution 
to a series of varied problems.

Knowledge is therefore acquired through 
trial and error, in an evolutionary learning logic that 
operates almost automatically, through inferences from 
accumulated knowledge.

For the belief system to be 
capable of understanding the new experiences that the individual 
faces, the latter must have the mental building blocks to 
solve the problems he or she is confronted with. 1.3. What place for emotion?

Described in this way, the belief construction model 
seems to leave almost no room for emotion.

However, some 
indications suggest that emotion, if it is not explicitly mobilized by institutional 
authors (Patalano, 2007, 2010), is indeed 
in the background of belief formation. This is particularly the case
when the authors mobilize Hayek (1960) by describing culture
as "the transmission over time of our stock of accumulated knowledge», a stock that includes « all human adaptations made to the environment and resulting from past experience » (North, 
2005, p. 77), such as habits, skills or even « emotional attitudes » (Mantazavinos et al., 2004, 
p. 77). Initially, Denzau and North (1994, p. 20) themselves had 
underlined the affective scope connoted by certain terms – such as that 
of « worker » or « capitalist » – within Marxist ideology.

However, North and his co-authors reduce the role of emotion to a mechanism for reinforcing beliefs. When the 
mental model has been confirmed (or not faulted) several times by 
signals from the environment, a stabilized belief is formed and a system of interconnected beliefs structured. This belief system itself becomes backed by a motivational system in which emotion plays a reinforcing role.

The emotional process makes it possible to reinforce the stability of this system when it has proven itself in the past: emotion therefore leads to the routinization of beliefs and, therefore, of the behaviors that result from them.
Emotion does not intervene in the formation of beliefs, it only confirms them.

Mental models and insufficiency of mental bricks
Mantzavinos et al. (2004) have a very pragmatic vision of the 
role of mental models. As we have emphasized, these 
allow the individual to interpret his environment. They are 
as such flexible and are constructed by the organism in response 
to a problematic situation.

The mental model corresponds to a 
successful prediction (or an expectation) that the individual forms about 
his environment before it sends him feedback. Depending 
on the degree of adequacy of this prediction with the feedback, the 
mental model is confirmed or refuted. Three polar cases then arise (Figure 1).

When the 
mental model is confirmed by the feedback, the belief system is stabilized. Having allowed the organism to survive in its environment, this 
system is linked to the motivational system which reinforces, via 
"the involvement of a parallel emotional adaptation" [Ibid.], its stability and its ability to filter 
new stimuli from the environment (path of the arrows (1)). If, however, the solution produced by the mental model 
has failed, the individual then resorts to the analogical or metaphorical model 
mentioned previously, and this, in a quasi-automatic way (path of the arrows (2)).

But what happens if the individual 
does not have the mental building blocks allowing him to solve the 
problems he is confronted with?

When the analogical approach 
does not work, the individual is then forced to become creative – that is, 
to invent new mental models and try new solutions (arrow path (2bis)). However, nothing is said in this model about how the individual 
can become creative himself.

Nothing is said either about the relationship 
between emotion and the creativity process. In summary from the above, it appears that feedback from the subject’s environment plays a determining role in 
the evolution of his belief system. If we follow Mantzavinos et 
al. (2004), the emotional process helps to reinforce the stability of 
this system when it has proven itself in the past: emotion 
therefore leads to the routinization of beliefs and, therefore, of behaviors

According to Dewey (1922, p. 88), “man is a creature of habit. No reason, nor yet instinct” where by “instinct” he means 
here what we might call an emotional impulse.

While, 
however, James relies on an individual conception of habit formation, Dewey pays much more attention to

While James also sees habit as one of society’s most conservative agents, “its [precious] flywheel” (James, 1931, 
p. 221), Dewey emphasizes its capacity for adaptation and flexibility. Dewey certainly does not conceive of repetition as the basis 
of habit.

Thus, "a tendency to repeat acts is the 
result of many habits, but not of all" (Dewey, 1922, 
p. 19).

text:
Furthermore, habit takes shape as "an acquired predisposition 
to [particular] modes of response" (Dewey, 1922, p. 19). As such, habit is anchored in a dynamic process 
of transaction between the organism and the environment. It is not a question of considering habit as something 
intangible norautomatic.

While it is true that a habit is all the more effective when it functions unconsciously, this is only true to the extent that it is not confronted with a situation that is beyond its control. Thus, “a problem in its functioning provokes emotions and reflections” (Dewey, 1922, p. 125). These problems, however, are not exceptions to routine behavior, because “at every moment, the complete equilibrium of the organism and its environment is constantly disturbed but also constantly restored” (Dewey, 1922, p. 125).

triplets.head: Dewey
triplets.tail: complete equilibrium of the organism and its environment

triplets.head: complete equilibrium of the organism and its environment

text: Furthermore, the steering and reshaping of action – which can lead to the formation of new, more effective habits – themselves depend on old habits that provide the material, the content, what is known and recognizable, from which the mode of action is recomposed (Jung, 2010, p. 155). Thus, habit and conscious action shape each other.

Habit should not therefore be considered “rigid, ordinary, thoughtless or explicitly memorized” (Cohen, 2007, p. 778). It is, in fact, only when they are separated or disjointed within the feedback loops between the organism and the environment that habit becomes rigid and degenerates into simple routine.
Dewey’s thinking is thus, above all, a thought of habit change. This change is directly in line with the pragmatist author’s philosophy of experience.

2.2. The transformation of habit via experience Dewey’s transformation of habit is inseparable from his philosophy of experience (Ballet and Petit, 2019). According to John Dewey, 
"[T]here is constant experience, because the interaction 5 of the living being and 
its environment is part of the very process of existence" 
5.

In his work in 1949, Dewey substituted the term "transaction" (which comes 
from the Latin word transactio and which means "to compromise") for that of "interaction".

In an 
article co-written with Arthur Bentley: "the term "interaction" [between the organism and 
the environment] is dangerous, since it is easy to understand that it involves 
two or more prior existences" (Dewey and Bentley, 1964, p 115). On the contrary, 
the transaction supposes that we take into account how the relationship between the subject and 
its environment has been built dynamically over time.

Bentley and 
Dewey (1949, p. 137) explain the difference in these terms: "if interaction presupposes 
that the organism and the objects surrounding it are present as substantially distinct 
existences or forms of existence […] [T]ransaction presupposes that no prior knowledge of the 
organism or the environment is necessary". We do not support this distinction in this 
article because it is not essential to follow Dewey's thinking on the point 
that concerns us.

Experience is therefore not a state of mind or a phenomenon for the organism; it is a unified, continuous, extended and yet rarely stabilized process. Several elements characterize this notion of experience.

An 
experience corresponds first of all to a tangible activity, an experimen - 
tationn, which involves manipulating things, introducing 
changes or modifying the logic of interaction between the subject and 
the object.

It is in this sense that experience “means an active and alert 
deal with the world” (Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 55). This activity 
then constitutes a vital function of the organism in the sense that it 
adapts to its environment at the same time as it adapts its

Experience is therefore “a more intense form of 
vitality” (Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 54). Finally, and we insist on this point, experience as an 
activity includes a significant part of innovation, creativity: the exact 
opposite of routine, experience involves an interruption in the usual 
course of our daily activities. Experience arises from a 
“disturbance” (from a “doubt” as Charles Sanders Peirce had suggested), from a 
“problematic situation”.

The situation is troubled either because 
the environment is contrary to our needs, or because the needs 
are contrary to the interests of the environment. Disturbance indicates 
a desire of the subject for change with the intention of restoring 
a balance: “harmony is achieved internally only when, 
by certain means, we conclude an agreement with our environment” 
(Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 51). An experience is particularly intended to modify a habit, 
a way of thinking, being or behaving, when it is 
unsuitable.

Experience is in fact an opportunity for the individual, immersed 
in his environment, to confront highly organized habits 
with impulses that are not. Impulses are “pivot points that motivate the reorganization or redirection of habits” (Cuffari, 2011, p. 538). They become crucial when the organism tends to act in a certain way in a particular situation (which may be changing) but does not have the resources to do so.

Previous habits then cease to be adapted to the present situation: action is hindered or constrained. In this

During these interactions between the organism and the environment, 
these moments of tension reveal a (permanent) movement of ebb and flow.

Rethinking the place of emotions with Dewey
Dewey’s theory of emotions (1894, 1895, 1896) is the fruit 
of a long-term work initiated in the mid-1890s, then 
clearly deepened and elaborated in later writings (Dewey, 
1910/2004, 1922, 1929, 1934/2005). In the pragmatist author, 
emotions are not considered as autonomous, 
isolated or purely internal phenomena, as most psychological 
theories of emotion often presuppose. They are not in particular a simple “externalization” (Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 123), an “immediate discharge” (Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 263), of an affect.

They are not universal but, much more, associated with a specific situation and a particular relationship. As Dewey indicates: “emotion in its ordinary sense is something provoked by objects, material and personal; it is a response to an objective situation…” (Dewey, 1925, p. 192, Dewey’s emphasis).

It is thus considered that the theoretical study of emotion must itself start from the notion of interaction between the organism and its environment and not focus on internal individual psychological states. In this 
sense, Dewey’s theory of emotions provides an appropriate framework for 
describing “the intimate relationship” (North, 2005, p. 75) between an 
individual’s belief system and institutions.

For Dewey (Dewey, 1925, p. 192), in fact, “emotion is the index 
of an intimate participation, more or less intense, in a scene 
in nature or in life”.

triplets.tail: emotion is the index of intimate participation

text:
More precisely, emotions are “attributes of a complex 
experience that progresses and evolves” (Dewey, 
1934/2005, p. 90). They are both at the origin of the experience and 
also effective operating modes of its unfolding andand its 
outcome.

Emotion therefore participates in the investigation procedure, born 
from the existence of a problematic situation.

It guides and directs reason, actively participating in what Dewey calls the method

Dewey's conception of emotion is in fact closer to an affective memory that is co-constructed continuously and dynamically in relation to our environment, the present situation and in proportion to what our personal history is. It is therefore very close, as indicated in particular by 
Johnson (2006), to the notion of somatic markers developed 
by Antonio Damasio (1995) 8. In the neurobiologist's theory, the individual begins by unconsciously apprehending the relevant elements of a situation or those 
of his close environment, which provokes cerebral reactions 
as well as peripheral or vagal modifications.

It is when 
the individual becomes aware of these reactions that he becomes aware 
of the emotion.

Thus, when a similar situation arises, it 
evoks the central cerebral representations of the body image linked 
to these peripheral modifications. These representations thus play the 
role of somatic markers which allow, when we are 
faced again with similar situations or events, to 
immediately become aware of the emotion, and to associate 
with it traits of appropriate action behaviors.

The marker would therefore function
as an emotional memory, a labeling of the event
or the landscape, as a warning or encouragement signal (innate or acquired) of cognitive and unconscious origin.

We can clearly grasp here the proximity that exists between Dewey and
Damasio (see Johnson, 2006), but also the way in which this schema
can be integrated into and especially extend the mental model envisaged by
North. The message of encouragement is obtained when the individual’s belief system
allows him to adapt to his environment.

This message allows him, at each new concordant opportunity, to reaffirm the beliefs of individuals and to stabilize them. His perceptions
(somatic markers) in this case reinforce his beliefs and 
orient his choices in an adaptive way. We are in the case, seen previously, where the mental model is confirmed by feedback and the system of beliefs stabilized (figure 1, path of arrows (1)).

However, somatic markers can send the organism a warning message, what Dewey (1910/2004, p. 101) could have called the “feeling of a contradiction” or a “difficulty”:

the method of intelligence which associates reason and emotion, that 
the individual can be creative and invent new ideas. There is indeed, 
as North suggests by evoking Kuhn himself (1962), the idea 
that a break is necessary to move from one system of thought (a 
paradigm) to another but it must be added the fact that emotion is a 
major triggering element of this break and that it also continually guides the process that will lead to these new 
ideas.

"Thinking is the only method that allows one to escape both 
impulse and routine" (Dewey, 1910/2004, p. 25).

In Dewey, in particular, emotions have the power to modify habits of thought (routines) because they represent something other than an “impulsive tendency [that] harms the act of thinking” (Ibid., p. 88). “For there to be reflection, the impulse must be to a certain extent hindered, turned back on itself” (Ibid).

It is here in particular that Dewey (1910/2004) announces the work of conceptualization achieved in Art as Experience (1934/2005) in which emotion – far from being an “immediate discharge” (Dewey, 1934/2005, p. 263) – is a way of conducting individual attitudes and a factor in transforming habits of thought. Emotions are at the heart of creativity. 4. C oncluSion
Institutional economics is an approach that emphasizes
“supra-individual units of analysis that cannot be reduced
to aggregations or direct consequences of the attributes or

motivations of individuals” (Powell and DiMaggio, p. 8, our translation). The neo-institutional approach proposes a crucial move beyond
institutionalism by reintroducing individual behavior to analyze changes in the rules. He proposes to return to the 
micro foundations of rules (Powell and Colyvas, 2008).

But as 
DiMaggio and Powell (1991) pointed out, the neo-institutional approach is located in the cognitive turn of social theories, and for 
this reason leaves emotions aside. Emotions themselves have long been tainted by an individual, even 
intimate, presupposition, which has led research towards decontextualized and decentered analyses of relationships with others (Gooty et al., 2009). Under these conditions, the bridge between institutional, then neo-institutional, economics and emotions seemed improbable (Voronov 
and Vince, 2012).

Like North and his colleagues, the neo-institutional movement has, however, 
focused on the role of emotions as an incentive 
to conform to institutions (Scott, 2008).

The feeling of shame 
has, for example, been mentioned as a catalyst for conformism (Scott, 
2008; Creed et al., 2014).

Voronov and Vince (2012) 
emphasize, for their part, that the emotional investment of individuals in 
institutions is a factor of primary importance for their reproduction. However, 
emotions are also a vector for institutional change, a motivational factor that 
overrides cognition (Voronov, 2014). Jasper and Poulsen (1995), 
for example, highlight the way in which feelings of fear and anger are used 
by protest groups to push for institutional change.

In this article, we have highlighted that the rereading of 
Dewey invites us to move away from the cognitive model of individual behavior 
proposed by the neo-institutional movement. It assumes taking into account 
emotional phenomena, which enriches the analysis of the link between 
the individual and the institution.

Emotion constitutes amissing piece
in recent institutional theory and its project. In a recent article, Denzau et al. (2016) highlight the 
failures of a system of thinking operating in a vacuum – “business as usual” (Ibid., p. 476) – which deprives institutions of 
organizational innovations. They in fact highlight the benefits of an organization turned more outward and mobilize in this context 
the virtues of communication.
